review.title: Evidence Algorithm and System for Automated Deduction: A Retrospective View
review.abstract: A research project aimed at the development of an automated theorem proving system was started in Kiev (Ukraine) in early 1960s. The mastermind of the project, Academician V.Glushkov, baptized it "Evidence Algorithm", EA. The work on the project lasted, off and on, more than 40 years. In the framework of the project, the Russian and English versions of the System for Automated Deduction, SAD, were constructed. They may be already seen as powerful theorem-proving assistants.
histories: To appear in The 9th International Conference on Mathematical Knowledge Management: MKM 2010
review.COMMENTS: To appear in The 9th International Conference on Mathematical Knowledge Management: MKM 2010
authors: konstantin verchinine kiev national taras shevchenko university

sections.heading: 3.2 Experimental work
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to determine for themselves what they want and what they don't want.

sections.heading: 3.3 Team evolution (or the sad part of the SAD history)
sections.text: Already at the end of 1972 V. Bodnarchuk fell seriously ill and stopped his research work for a long time. From 1973 to 1975 F. Anufriev, Z. Aselderov, V. Kostyrko and A. Malashonok left the team for various reasons, after that they never returned to the department. In 1982 V. Glushkov was dead. The administrative style of the Institute of Cybernetics changed and we were no longer the preferred team of directors. In the middle of 1983 A. Lyaletski and A. Zhezherun left the Kiev University. In 1984 K. Werchinine moved to another department and changed his field of research. In 1987 A. Degtyarev finally went to the Kiev University. M.Morochovets stayed in our former department of the Institute of Cybernetics. The EA team no longer existed...

sections.heading: 4 Post-EA Stage and English SAD (1998-nowadays)
sections.text: This year it will be able to ernei the aforementioned lcihsrcsrteeSe rfü eid eerwtlrteeeirsrteeGe, rfü ide sasd rfü eid nlrsrteeoiKe to eren.ngteeeitln

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: Imagine an ideal mathematical wizard. What might its architecture look like from the position of the EA? A user communicates with the system using texts written in a high formal input language similar to the natural one. He or she presents a problem such as "verify whether the given text is correct" or "how to prove the following statement," or "what the given text is about," etc. The text, if it is syntactically correct, is dealt with by the part of the system we call "more reasonable." The sensible one analyzes the problem and formulates a series of tasks that he submits to the inference machine, a tester. If the tester succeeds, the resulting conclusion (e.g., human readable evidence) is given to the user and the game is over. If it fails, a kind of "morbid anatom" makes a diagnosis and delivers it to the tester who tries to fix the situation. Specifically, the reasonable one can decide whether the problem can be addressed by an internal lexicon and the system can answer it.

sections.heading: 6 Acknowledgements
sections.text: We are grateful for our teachers. We are grateful to all who have worked side by side with us throughout this time. Special thanks to the referees for their patience. Cybersel experiments. Cybersel experiments. Cybersel experiments. Cybersel experiments. Cybersel experiments.

Bodnarchuk was the head of a computer department; its members had just finished their work under a specialized mini-computer for engineering computation with the language “Analitik” [11].

Bodnarchuk has formulated the following tasks: - careful revision of everything that was done previously by the “old team”; - detailed analysis of mathematical texts in various domains; - preparation of two surveys: (1) of combinatorial proof-search methods (published, see [16]) and (2) of using heuristics in proof search (published, see [18]) The revision of the existing version of the AGS method demonstrated that, first, the use of the Kanger’s notion of substitution admissibility instead of skolemization complicates drastically an eventual implementation and, second, the method requires a special technique for equality handling.

metadata.abstractText: A research project aimed at the development of an automated theorem proving system was started in Kiev (Ukraine) in early 1960s. The mastermind of the project, Academician V.Glushkov, baptized it “Evidence Algorithm”, EA3. The work on the project lasted, off and on, more than 40 years. In the framework of the project, the Russian and English versions of the System for Automated Deduction, SAD, were constructed. They may be already seen as powerful theoremproving assistants. The paper4 gives a retrospective view to the whole history of the development of the EA and SAD. Theoretical and practical results obtained on the long way are systematized. No comparison with similar projects is made.
